output: Thank you.

President, first of all, congratulations to the rapporteur, Ms. Sarnec, for her excellent synthesis work, especially in a context where the Commission and, even more so, the Councils have not always shown great openness towards the requests of this Parliament.
The Development Commission unanimously approved my report; some of our observations were taken into account, while we remain rather dissatisfied with other points.

However, we take a step back, with a sense of responsibility, considering it paramount to secure the approval of the entire package at first reading, thus ensuring the commencement of the process on January 1st next year.

I believe, therefore, that the path we have taken is a good one.
However, and this is where the invitation comes in, efforts in terms of communication still need to be stepped up.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, honorable colleagues, our primary goal is to ensure for Europe a common agricultural policy even after 2013.

We believe that this is fundamental not only for safeguarding the agricultural sector and the socio-economic fabric in the Member States, but also because, at the dawn of the third millennium, it is more strategically necessary than ever to ensure Europe's food security.

Madam Commissioner, we wish to emphasize that it is necessary to continue implementing support policies for individual CMO where required, and in particular, we believe that:

a. In the tobacco sector, the decoupling of aid should provide for the possibility of

maintain a partial coupled aid until 2013, in order to prevent the complete abandonment of production, as this would put entire supply chains at risk, creating unemployment as well as various economic and environmental problems in particularly disadvantaged areas.
I would like to remind the Commissioner and the President that the European Parliament has already expressed its support by a large majority on this issue.

B. In the dairy sector, in order to rebalance the market in the short term and to allow for a soft landing of the quota system in the long term, it would be appropriate to increase quotas by 2% for each marketing year from 2009-2010 to 2014-2015. Thank you.
Madam Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, I am very pleased to regard this as a very positive test of
co-decision in agricultural matters that was achieved through enhanced cooperation between the Council, the Commission, and the European Parliament.
It is a good omen, and it will also allow me, of course, to congratulate Mr. Capolassantos on his balanced approach.
report on modulation, young farmers, workplace safety, as well as in the face of new challenges.
We are going through a challenging transition, embracing innovation such as the ProdO and decoupling. In this transition, we must safeguard industrial livestock farmers.
given the abandonment of milk quotas, as well as disadvantaged areas such as those in the tobacco sectors. We must take advantage of this transition to initiate a serious reflection on
after 2013 to update the objectives and new missions of the CAP and to begin discussing the overcoming of the dichotomy between the first and second pillars.

President, I appreciate the great efforts of our rapporteur Capolassantos to keep the CAP closer to farmers and European citizens, rather than market demands, and to reconcile the various concerns in the face of the many challenges at stake.
Therefore, a common approach by the 27 States in this sector is indispensable, but it is important to maintain support and market management tools for the main productions.

I think, for example, of the dairy sector or tobacco subsidies. Their abolition would certainly not contribute to reducing smoking, but rather to the elimination of an important European production and the social fabric associated with it.
These tools must, however, always take into account the extremely diverse reality of the European landscape.
The currently valid milk quota system, for example, is based on now-obsolete criteria.
and the 1% increase proposed in the compromise is not sufficient to meet the internal demand of most Member States.

What is needed, therefore, is a more flexible system that gives each individual Member State the possibility to respond to its own needs, which would also enhance the European competitiveness of the sector in the international market.
Mr. President, our group is quite satisfied with these two proposals.

The quantity of amendments we have attempted to contribute to the improvement of these texts demonstrates this sufficiently, if not entirely, and we are rather satisfied with a lack of ambition. We believe that more and better could have been achieved.

There are signs of openness, of civilization, which are immediately followed, at times even in the debate within this Parliament, by signals of rigidity, especially from the Council, of great, strong protectionism.

This also concerns the blue card. There is resistance to some central principles, equal work, equal pay, which is a sacred and natural principle, but even on this point we have found some traces of harshness.
We believe it is essential to move beyond the principle of community preference, to overcome the idea of a two-speed Europe, which is why the principle of community preference must be upheld.
We believe that the emphasis on the labor market is important, but the labor market cannot be the sole governing principle.
There are other inclusive principles of political and social civilization that must be within immigration policies.
Legal immigration means equal dignity and opportunities, or we return to choosy immigration, selected, partial, and discriminatory.
We would like to avoid it.

For this reason as well, on behalf of the group, I support the proposal by colleague Moreno, addressed to the Commission. Let us consider a blue card that is not only linked to that 3% of highly qualified immigrants, but that also seeks to find legal and concrete tools to open the market to immigration.
Immigration must be inclusion; if it becomes a choice, it is no longer a positive policy.

Honorable Marco, Honorable Marco, could you spare a moment? In the face of the extremely severe crisis that is affecting the automotive industry from America to our continent, Europe is confronted with a very clear dilemma. Either it remains inert, observing this collapse in demand and production, or it intervenes with a coordinated and ambitious plan to support the sector.

production, the effects of which are not even calculable today, in the name of an abstract consistency for a theoretical model of market liberalism, of total respect for competition, as some voices have also been heard today, or to take responsibility to adequately address the situation.
We are decidedly in favor of this second option, and we call on the Commission and the Council for decision and determination.
We appreciated Commissioner Ferroigen's words and hope that some colleagues do not temper this determination too much.
This is an exceptional situation, therefore the responses must also be exceptional.

Moreover, dear colleagues, the financial crisis has revealed certain actions taken by political and economic authorities, making decisions regarding public resource allocation and behavior that were unthinkable just a few months prior.

But our intervention, and I conclude, must be selective, reconciling strategy with emergency, and supporting, through both favorable credits and demand support, a selective orientation towards environmentally more sustainable productions.

It escapes no one that the topic is sensitive, involving significant industrial and commercial processes, and thus the difficulty of ratifying a system of control and regulation by all States, especially the Member States, is understandable.

However, the escalating nature of these events and the awareness that internal and external arms trafficking exists illegally, underscores the urgency of regulating this sector in a legally effective manner.
Even the directive currently being drafted on intracommunity transfers of defense-related goods will have real meaning if the code of conduct is promptly ratified.
I regret that the incumbent Prime Minister has left, but after the things he said, I will overlook some other aspects I had prepared. After his statements, it seems that everything is in order.

Can greater Europe afford to welcome or speak to, accept, listen to the Dalai Lama? Why is this?
I believe it is clear. We know that the European people, if consulted as European citizens, would support the Dalai Lama by 80%.
I am
those who argue that the 2020 European directive imposes overly high costs on the European Union's economy.
Among these is the Italian Government, which has presented cost estimates that are almost double, without particularly convincing evidence.

However, such positions underestimate the future price of fossil fuels and overlook the significant benefits stemming from the rapid spread of renewable energies, such as supply security, but above all the creation of new jobs at a time of recession when thousands of workers are being expelled from production processes.
Increased energy efficiency and the widespread use of renewable energy sources are the recipe for exiting the economic crisis.
Concentrating a large portion of public funds to save banks means proposing the same economic model, entirely based on finance, that created the crisis we are trying to combat.
The economic situation cannot be tackled without strategic changes.
The EU directive aims at innovation and, above all, seeks to address in a timely manner the disruptions caused by the climate change that is already underway.
A problem that will increasingly weigh on the lives of European citizens and the economies of member states.
That's why public investments should not once again support traditional sectors, but should focus on activities that bring innovation in the energy and environmental fields.
Key factors for the growth of the renewable energy sector are the development of distribution networks and priority access to these networks.
Between the 1960s and 1980s, the enormous expenses for network infrastructure and large centralized systems were supported by significant public investments.
This aspect must also hold true to ensure the future of the energy system based on renewables.
Therefore, renewable energy generation plants must be managed with new technologies. This requires investments, research, and the development of technologies.
There remains an urgency to adopt this package at first reading during the December plenary session, as expected by European citizens.
We cannot allow the short-sightedness of certain states and economic interests to block this process.
Thank you, President. For the sake of future memory, if the future will have a memory, we are witnessing a genetic transformation of that Parliament and of that European Union, President, which
In 85, she came to know well and contributed at that time to bringing to life the European homeland, countering the disastrous illusion of the old Europe of nations.
Today, we are moving in that direction every day.
Even yesterday, the day before yesterday, at the Council, the Europe from the Atlantic to the Urals was evoked once again, an old nationalist memory rather than a European one.
The Europe of Calergi, but also of Winston Churchill, whose names adorn our Parliament.
They were for the United States of Europe, today we do nothing but talk about partnerships to all those who instead want to be members, to be Europe, and I believe we are holding them back.
Delivering all of them, look towards the Mediterranean, to a fate that is certainly dangerous and certainly affecting the Europeans and democrats of those countries.
Thank you all.

many aspects of the work-life balance, of the work-life relationship, and of the work-guarantees relationship, and it is a choice that weakens the rights of workers, which are then the rights of all of us, of our children, of ordinary people.
And I would not want this speech to be mistaken as syndicalist or corporatist, because I defend the healthcare personnel.
No, that is not the case. As a politician, I do not act on behalf of corporations or unions. I act on behalf of the citizens.
I think of them when I make choices, I think of their social rights, which for me are fundamental in Europe.

I therefore do not believe that it is a good Europe, one that does not move forward while the world progresses, and indeed makes glaring errors of perspective, confusing the weakening of protections with flexibility and freedom.
And this is all the more serious at a time when Europe is experiencing its worst crisis and sees no prospects for prosperity and growth.

If we do not understand, Mr. President of the Council, representatives of the Council and the Commission, if we do not grasp that at this very moment millions of workers are at risk of losing their jobs and feel in a state of weakness and precariousness,

And they certainly do not have the contractual and voluntary capacity, let alone the option to opt-out, then I must say that we do not have an understanding of what is really happening in the social and family life of Europeans.
For this reason, we will support the proposals of the SERGAS editor, and we hope that the entire Parliament will do the same.
I must say that the Council's unwillingness to negotiate at this stage forces us to seek a platform for discussion and negotiation during the conciliation process.
Thank you, President. We are faced with an important compromise for Europe, even if the European Parliament had to swallow a few toads.
In essence, the text on renewables emerging from the trilogue contains a clear definition of the objectives and, above all, of their mandatory nature.

The 2014 revision clause is to be interpreted as providing greater flexibility to achieve the reduction target, which remains at 20%, and, if conditions allow, to push for a further reduction of up to 30% by 2020.

It is important to emphasize that the most powerful and economically advantageous flexibility tool for Member States lies in national efficiency measures in the construction, transport, industry sectors, and in the improved use of electricity.
The mandatory 10% target for biofuels should be qualified with efficiency requirements in the transformation processes, through the authorization of environmental and social sustainability criteria.
The use of biomass should be directed towards non-controversial areas, towards conversion technologies that are more efficient than first- and second-generation biofuels.
The agreement reached by the Council and the will of the European Parliament send a positive message. It is impossible to tackle the extremely serious economic crisis without strategic changes.
Those, like Berlusconi, who mocked European directives, referring to them as a Don Quixote-like plan, have been defeated.

The package that this Parliament is called upon to approve, despite the watering down due to the selfish interests of the Member States, moves towards providing innovative solutions to mitigate the impact of climate change.
If we do not act quickly, this problem will weigh more heavily on the European economy, but especially on the lives of European citizens.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I am very grateful first of all to the Chairman of the Agriculture Committee of the European Parliament, colleague Parish, for
having promoted this question following the important hearing of experts that we conducted in the same Committee.
It is undeniable that the Mediterranean diet is part of the historical and cultural heritage of our continent, just as its health-promoting principle is undeniable.
The same Commission, in the White Paper on Obesity, identified it as a natural medicine absolutely suitable.
The health benefits are scientifically proven and enjoy widespread popularity abroad, starting with the United States.
And so it happens that the concept expands to the point of distorting its originality.
For this reason, recognition by UNESCO establishes a definition to protect this peculiarity. And I want to tell colleague Parish that
Due to the peculiarities of European gastronomic culture today, we discuss the Mediterranean diet, but certainly not as the only peculiarity of European culinary richness.
Commissioner, you have honored your predecessor's commitment to recognize the importance of this initiative, and I thank you for that.
emphasizing that she has no decision-making power within the UNESCO procedure, however, I believe she can express an opinion, a contribution.

President, let's start with one concept: the Mediterranean diet. Abundant studies confirm that it promotes the fight against obesity and cardiovascular diseases, and in general, it is highly beneficial for human health in numerous ways.

But the point here is not to claim to impose the Mediterranean diet across the entire EU or to try to favor it over other dietary patterns that are better suited to different climates and regions of the Mediterranean.
It is, however, our duty to protect it, to define its content and characteristics, in order to safeguard it from imitations and external influences that could harm its image and value.
Therefore, it should be valued, like all other European cultural expressions, which deserve to be defended and promoted at a global level.
It is a model that the world tries to copy. Therefore, it is important to specify its peculiarities and protect it, to prevent a fully European heritage from being lost in the sea of globalization.

The automotive sector crisis has escalated into a crisis encompassing an entire industry, affecting related sectors' supply chains, commercial networks, and subsequently, services. This situation presents dramatic prospects in terms of employment.

I believe that even the dramatic drop in these latest enrollments, which for this month is reported as a decrease of 33% in some Member States, 20% in others, and so on, demonstrates that this is not a crisis of a technologically obsolete sector. It does not originate within the sector itself, nor within this or that company due to managerial errors.
This is a systemic crisis and as such it must be urgently and decisively addressed by the European institutions themselves.
Some remedies seem to be identified, but it is important how to implement them, with what resources, and with what innovation perspectives.
Certainly, the demand must be supported. Consumption is the only driver of recovery.

But in the meantime, while this response, supporting consumption, is being implementeda medium-term responseI believe we must state that immediate credit support is needed to resume production, pay for materials, and sustain employment, even in the face of declining orders and demand.
Thus the credit sector, but as we were saying, the way in which it is done is important.
And here, too, I call for a stronger role for Europe. It is important that European institutions set an example.

America is intervening, some European countries are doing so as well, and I too hope that my country moves from generic proposals to concrete initiatives. I also hope for a stronger European action in the recovery plan and beyond.

Because I believe, and our commissioner has also stated in some way, that the fate of the great European houses is a common one, and the great European producers must not face competition within the commercial market.

common in the form of various types of state aid or incentives, but they must be met with a strong, decisive, and coordinated response from Europe, because the fate of the European automotive market is measured by its ability to face global competition together.

And there is the other point that has been raised, as Sacconi stated, which I reiterate: support should not be mere aid or, worse, assistance that leaves everything as is, but rather an incentive to develop fundamental competitive capabilities.
in the sector in terms of innovations, environmentally compatible productions, and also more environmentally and passenger-safe technologies and transportation.
with satisfaction at Belarus's new willingness to cooperate with the European Union and the international community.
We are very cautious with Lukashenko, but we welcome a new approach in this context.
We will not tire of emphasizing the need for a comprehensive and substantial change of course in the context of respecting human rights.

On one point, I believe the Commission could demand clearer and more straightforward behavior from MISC. I am referring to the situation of the children, tens of thousands of whom are hosted for several months in European families.

For several years, the Belarusian government has adopted absurd and at times incomprehensible attitudes, frequently canceling the stays of minors at the last minute, much to the dismay of the families.
hosting them and delivering a new, resounding slap to the children who, often orphans and coming from very complicated family situations, have been completely affected by it.
In this matter, we aim to achieve a change of course as soon as possible.
Reading the text of this document, one gets the impression that its author desires not an improvement but a deterioration of relations between the European Union and Russia.
If this is the goal of Europe, then this document is excellent. If it is not, then it is poor.
And I believe it to be a terrible document.
How could we envision a future of new tensions with a country whose indispensability we recognize in our own interest?
In the next 40 years, we will have to rely on traditional energy resources of which Russia is rich. Can we do otherwise?
I cannot.
Secondly, the manner and tone. In these pages, Europe speaks in an imperial language, not the language of one who respects their interlocutor.
This contradicts our very policy of good neighborliness and would not be right, even towards a small country, let alone towards a large country that rightly claims to be respected.

It is a matter of realism, above all. The European Parliament is about to approve, I fear, a document written in the spirit of the Cold War, outdated, useless, harmful, and counterproductive, at a time when the new American President is seeking to establish a new dialogue with Moscow.
With this approach, Europe cannot aspire to any leadership, and I hope that the Commission does not accept these recommendations.
Thank you, President. I appreciate the rapporteur's proposal, however, this resolution refers too much not only in this point and in this note of the proposed oral amendment,

but in many other parts of the resolution, it refers to all Member States for different reasons, it also refers to the same subject matter that you request to be deleted from the note, regarding the same subjects in other parts of the resolution.

Therefore, Mr President, I believe it would be appropriate for the colleague, and this is my proposal, to bring back the resolution, request further amendments, and then refer it back to the Committee for re-examination.
of what has occurred within FIETA here in Brussels.

many large European multinationals that then, on the contrary, benefit from the rules, often also from the subsidies of the nation-states and the European Union, and that, on the other hand, do not respect workers' rights.
Thank you, Mr. President, dear colleagues. I would like to thank the Chair, the Commission, the Chair of the Committee on Energy and Industry, Mr. Nibbler, and my fellow members.
rapporteurs for this energy package, the Shadow rapporteurs, the Commission secretariat with all its officials for their cooperation and the expertise shown on this file.
We can and must all be proud of the result achieved. I am, considering the effort made when I inherited the directive on the internal gas market, with issues that were not easily resolvable.

I am pleased to have aligned my second experience as a Member of the European Parliament with the final stage of this package, which I consider to be one of the most important files of this legislative term in favor of our European citizens, who are our voters.
The gas directive, which will come into force from 2011, brings significant novelties to the sector. It is important to highlight the achievement of option I as a notable result.
which guarantees the opening of markets and a real progression towards a system that truly allows the European Union to speak with one voice on energy matters.
The ITO is the real novelty of this package and it is on this aspect that one can say the European Parliament has achieved the best result.
The new gas directive places great importance on the gas authority and the agency.
This directive legitimizes the authorities in their role, especially in those countries where they must start their activities from scratch.

Therefore, it is of fundamental importance to have defined the role and competencies of these bodies, and to have granted them extensive powers, as it is the authorities' difficult task to oversee the common energy market.
Another element that was included during the trilogue is the exemption from common rules for so-called closed systems, namely airports, hospitals, stations, industrial sites, etc.
Their particular peculiarities. They are subject to a more favorable regime, which demonstrates the attention that the new directive gives to the needs of the European citizen.

It is the European citizen, in my opinion, who will truly benefit from this directive, as through the use of smart meters, they will have access to all information related to their bill and will be able to evaluate the best offer on the market and choose their supplier absolutely.

according to convenience. Because while it is true that years will pass before the effects of this liberalization are seen, it is nonetheless undeniable that the entry of new operators into the market will lead to a lowering of prices and more favorable market conditions for Union citizens.
Another important element is the recognition of European gas transmission networks, which will ensure the security of gas supply to European citizens.
All of this also involves the reinforcement and creation of new infrastructure, such as regulators and storage facilities, which will be the driving force behind the third package.
Therefore, the opening of a competitive market is required to guarantee long-term investments and contracts by companies in the sector.
especially in the new member states, where the creation of new infrastructure would also enable the resolution of long-standing dependency issues.
Consumer protection for the most vulnerable was taken into account, providing national and regional authorities with the possibility to ensure their gas supply during the most critical times.
The successful outcome of the gas directive and the entire energy package once again highlights the role of Europe and its institutions for European citizens.

On one occasion, we find ourselves in this Chamber to defend a food, cultural, and rural heritage stemming from a centuries-old tradition, an invaluable asset that the world envies us, representing a huge wealth for the economy and also for the identity of our Union.

A heritage that today risks finding itself in serious difficulty due to the will of the Commission and the Council to abolish the Coupage ban for the production of ros wines, a will born under strong pressures.

pressures and that it will be ratified without the possibility of intervention by the Parliament, the body that officially represents the millions of citizens, both producers and consumers, who will be affected by this initiative.

The Commission proposes to allow the production of red wines by simply blending red and white wines, as do countries that do not possess our expertise and professionalism, under the mere pretext of responding to international competition.
As the co-signatory of the inquiry, I emphasize that lowering the quality of our productions, the result of centuries of traditions and research, of significant investments, and of passion,

and attention to detail is not the response we need, especially in a time of economic crisis like this one, where the average consumer is undoubtedly more focused on price than on any writing on the label.

To counterbalance this decision, it would be sufficient to find a name for the new product and inform consumers about the existence of two different types of ros, the different quality of the products, and the importance of recognizing the work and efforts of professionals in the sector.
Who will pay for all this?

Does the Commission have any support programs in this regard, or will producers once again be left to pay, after being asked to fight against low-cost competition with unequal weapons during already extremely difficult times?
I hope that the Council's Commission is able to make the right choice and, if necessary, completely revise this procedure.
Thank you. Mr. President, allow me first of all to greet the President of the DTP Party, Mr. Ahmet Turk, who is here with us in the gallery of honor and who is following the debate.
Dear Ahmet, know that we stand in solidarity with you, supporting the democratic struggle your party leads in Turkey for the recognition of the fundamental rights of the Kurdish people.
We recognize the HDP as an indispensable tool for the promotion of democracy in Turkey, and for this reason, we firmly condemn the police operations that have been carried out against it.
Prime Minister Erdogan has issued orders against you, imprisoning all three vice presidents of the DTP along with over 300 activists and sympathizers.
The victory of the DTP in the recent local elections demonstrates that the DTP party enjoys strong democratic popular support.

The European Parliament, in its resolutions, has called on Prime Minister Erdogan to engage in direct discussions with the DTP, but his response has been more repression, more police, more authoritarianism, and more imprisonment.

Everyone is aware that my parliamentary group and the Left in Europe have until now supported the process of Turkey's accession to the European Union, while also backing the reform process in that country.

However, I believe that in these last two years and especially in recent months, Erdogan has shown another face, that of a leader compromised with the worst elements of the Turkish army, who simply want to massacre the Kurds.
The reform process is practically dead, and prisons are filling up with Kurds. Erdogan himself is closing any perspective of Turkey's accession.
It is your responsibility and yours alone for what is happening in Euro-Turkish relations and the growing perplexity of European public opinion towards Turkey.

I want to send a very strong political message to Erdogan. Either he makes the pursuit of a negotiated political solution to the Kurdish issue a priority, which, let it be clear, goes through direct negotiations with the DTP, or we will be the ones to call for the suspension of the accession negotiations with the European Union.

The path of Turkey's accession to the Union goes through Diarcavira and the DTP, otherwise it will be us, those who have until now supported the accession process, who will call for a reflection period that risks being definitive.

Thank you, President. I would like to thank the Council for sharing these principles, and above all, if you allow me, Commissioner Barroco, with whom I had a very fruitful dialogue that was extremely helpful in the work we then presented in the House.

I would like to express my heartfelt thanks to the colleagues who worked on this report, providing me with ideas and, of course, contributing their vast experience. First and foremost, I am grateful to Mr. Demetriu, Baroness Ladford, and the excellent President Depri.

I would like to state that what Demetri, Latford, and Depr say is precisely the most important thing, it is the challenge of the European Union, because achieving a unified European judicial culture is paramount.
Of course, in engaging in a serious debate on what Depr says, the independence of justice, guarantees, and addressing the disparities among various judicial systems are the challenges that lie ahead.
but I believe that the work we have done allows us to be optimistic.

I would like to address the Honorable Romagnoli and say that, from my perspective, which should also be yours, there is undoubtedly a sense of pessimism about the Italy of reason. However, we must have an opinion.

the optimism of the will and the work that you too, Honourable Romagnoli, have done, and the contribution you have made to the report, mean that we can all together build the European Union, and the European Union is a reality also for us Italians.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, it seems that the thousands of deaths we have seen so far due to asbestos, the tens of thousands of deaths we have witnessed due to asbestos,
of people who risk dying in the coming years due to past exposure to asbestos. The latency period, as we know, can reach 15 and even 20 years. They absolutely count for nothing.

It seems that the Eternit trial that began in Turin counts for nothing regarding what happened in Casale Monferrato, where there is not a single family that has not experienced a bereavement within its ranks.
Asbestos should have been effectively banned by Member States through the application of the 1999 directive.

States should have protected exposed workers with all possible precautions, implementing the 2003 directive, closing facilities, remediating contaminated sites, and compensating victims and affected populations.
This did not happen everywhere.
Little or nothing has been done.
I have already spoken about the Turin trial, where Swiss and Belgian owners are defendants.
Everyone knew, little was done, and it is primarily the industry that shirks its responsibilities, acting within the gaps of inertia and public authorities.
Examples of inertia can be seen, for instance, in Italy: in Brioni where asbestos has not been removed, in Porto Marghera, and in Cengio, where deaths are still being counted.
Today, the industry is requesting that the Commission tolerate another derogation, already granted for a limited time by the Rich Regulation in 2006, for chrysotile asbestos fibers.

It is true, they have a limited application to low-voltage electrolysis plants and only in a few facilities, but where industry leaders claim impossibility for any alternative substitute as soon as the plants close.

A threat, but alternatives to this process have been found in Sweden, utilizing technologies for the replacement of asbestos-free membranes for low voltage, and a similar solution was also adopted for the production of hydrogen.
Why in some states yes and in others no?
Why, in the long battle for the ban on PCBs, were there countless omissions and hesitations to act, even with the support of the European Commission's Directorate-General for Enterprises?
Even in this case, a poor example has been set.
The 1999 directive on the prohibition of asbestos required that the review of such authorization be preceded by an opinion from the Scientific Committee on Toxicology, which was never provided.
Is this how the Commission respects the directives?
Not to mention the union, which claims it was not even consulted.
The European Parliament makes its own effort to catch up with others in compliance.

This resolution calls on the Commission to fill, by 2009, a legislative gap regarding the banning of second-hand products containing asbestos, roof tiles, aircraft parts, and any other items that should be definitively disposed of.
They set precise dates, once again for a strategy to ban all types of asbestos by 2015, but these were already goals written in 1999.
Ten years have passed and people have continued to die.
The EU had claimed, among the first initiatives of this legislative term, the establishment of a community compensation fund for victims, and ad hoc funds for decontamination.
The request was specific to the Commission, which today, however, yields to the will of multinational corporations.
It is necessary, instead, to move on to concrete commitment actions.
Only when these stem from the very requests of this resolution, only then can we be understanding.
Today, this will is not evident, therefore we vote against the granting of the derogation.

Thank you, Mr. President. I wished to convey to President Buzek the pride that fills me at this moment in belonging to an important institution such as the European Parliament, which you preside over.
I believe that the sacrifices made by your country over the past twenty years, and which today are reflected in the twelve nations previously mentioned in this assembly, lend strength to Europe.
However, I also wish to convey my concern after listening to your program as part of your speech, which should, and I hope will, strengthen this Parliament.
I hope that what you have announced will come to pass.

I hope that the next President of the European Commission, certainly President Barroso, will want to listen to her for the strong words she has spoken to ensure that this Parliament provides answers to more than

The 550 million citizens who voted for us in this Europe, who wanted and want and demand from this Parliament, from all of us, the answers that Europe has certainly tried to provide, but has not fully succeeded in giving.
Upon this endeavor of yours, I set my hopes in motion and I am certain that with you we will manage to attain the certainties that it has lodged within us.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, honorable colleagues, it is not my intention, nor that of my group, which has supported and requested this debate, to transfer attributes of Italian domestic policy to the European level.

The issue of freedom of information concerns all of us and the European Union, which can and must regulate the matter at the community level in order to counter political and economic pressures and to guarantee genuine pluralism in information.

The Italian anomaly, where the Prime Minister is also the owner of some of the most important private networks, lies precisely in the existence of a dangerous entanglement between media, political, and economic powers.

It is precisely for this reason that we are calling for European regulatory intervention, an intervention that, far from being an act of anti-Italian sentiment, aims to protect media pluralism by preventing concentrations of ownership and conflicts of interest.

For this reason, today we call on the Commission to act as soon as possible, as this Parliament has also requested in the past, to equip the European Union with common rules to protect the freedom of information for all European citizens.
Thank you, President. I am aware that on September 30th, the Commission presented a study on media pluralism indices in the Member States.
But in 2008, a report was adopted, drafted by Marianne Micco, which called on the European Commission and the Member States to protect, I quote verbatim, "the multiplicity"
of opinions in the media, to defend the pluralism of information, to ensure that all citizens of the European Union have equal access to free and diverse media.

Even earlier, in 2004, a report by Ms Bogert-Quack on the risks of violations of freedom of expression and information in the European Union was adopted in Parliament, calling on the Commission to present a communication on the guarantee of media pluralism in all Member States.
To date, the Commission has not yet provided clear responses to the Parliament's requests.

You will notice, Commissioner, that I have not mentioned my country or my Prime Minister, but as a European citizen, I ask you here what the Commission intends to do at European level to ensure that media pluralism is guaranteed in all Member States.
Thank you.

Now we must intervene with appropriate means and resources to prevent and eradicate a scourge as widespread as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and other diseases that are destined to increase with the aging of the population.

Honorable President, we were in Ramallah when the news arrived that Europe had adopted a new decision on the peace process in the Middle East.
We have witnessed the smile of hope on the faces of the Palestinian representatives.

These were intense days of emotions and sufferings, etched onto the faces of children clinging to the window grates of their homes, on a street in Hebron, the ghost street that no Palestinian can cross.

The suffering of an 85-year-old woman evicted from her home, forced to sleep in the cold in a tent pitched in the garden of what had been her house. The suffering etched on the faces of those Palestinians who, with European funding, had built a farm later destroyed by Israeli soldiers.
Israel has the right to be an independent state, but Palestinians also have the right to have a homeland, a state, and a passport.
The decision by the Council of Europe represents a significant step forward, but action must be taken immediately.
The conflict between Israel and Palestine is the tip of the iceberg of a larger conflict.
On the final day of the visit, the Israeli authorities prevented us, the European Parliament delegation, from visiting the Gaza Strip.
I believe that on this matter, the High Representative, Baroness Ashton, should intervene to make the voice of democratic Europe heard.

I would like to thank President De Rossa, who led the delegation, and all its other members. During our stay in Palestine, the Palestinians who are vulnerable were able to see and hear the face and the words of a Europe that defends rights and wants and must do more.

Thank you, Mr. President. Honourable colleagues, the topic of good fiscal governance, while always having been of great importance, has gained even greater relevance and significance in the aftermath of the major economic and financial crisis of two years ago.
International summits, such as the G20 and European gatherings, have discussed and continue to debate these issues, especially when addressing the fight against tax evasion and tax havens.
All this is important, it is a sign of commitment and determination, but one must not delude oneself that an announcement is enough.
A serious and consistent policy is needed.
Many problems remain.
It is still far too easy to buy or set up a shell company to evade taxes.
Simply take a look on the internet. There are thousands of websites offering companies for sale, even in European Union countries.
And often, it is enough to send an email with an attached scanned copy of the passport to be able to open a company.
The practice of creating fictitious legal entities to evade taxation must be put to an end.
This report that I am presenting is based on the European Commission's communication on good fiscal governance of April 28, 2009.
The report is aimed at putting forward concrete proposals and calls for a strong commitment from the European Commission and the Council to implement these proposals.
The European Union must prioritize the fight against tax havens, tax evasion, and illicit capital flight.
From here stems the principle of good governance, based on transparency, information exchange, cross-border cooperation, and fair tax competition.
The point is that there is a growing need for fiscal cooperation and collaboration within the European Union.
The overall goal we should aim for is to achieve automatic information exchange on a global and multilateral scale, starting, of course, from the European Union.
As already stated by colleague Alvarez, we must completely abolish bank secrecy in European Union countries and put an end to the derogation regime without further delay.
temporary measure authorizing the application of a withholding tax at source, often evaded or underestimated, in lieu of information exchange.
I do not intend to elaborate on the specific proposals contained in the report.
I emphasize that we still need some specific points. Extending the scope of the 2003 Savings Directive, combating VAT fraud, and establishing a public register of the European Union.
that takes into account individuals or businesses that have established companies or opened accounts in tax havens. Reconfirm and relaunch fiscal harmonization projects starting from

from the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base. It is also necessary for the European Union to speak with one voice internationally, advocating for the improvement of OECD regulations to achieve automatic information exchange instead of exchange upon request.

I must admit that when we talk about counter-terrorism, discussing only intelligence and technology, I always get the impression that we are examining the issue inadequately, as if we wanted to cure a disease by focusing solely on its symptoms and not its causes.
Is it not high time to tackle the problem of terrorism, aiming at the core of the issue rather than merely focusing on its outward phenomenology?

Addressing the core of the issue means, for instance, acknowledging that terrorism is also a direct manifestation of the inability or unwillingness of ethnic groups to integrate into the European cultural fabric.
I wonder and ask this Parliament, do we want to discuss terrorism?
So, let this Parliament have the courage to politically address a debate on the degree of integration of Muslims in Europe and their willingness to share Western values, rights, and freedoms.
In this regard, I have submitted a question to the Commission on the full-face veil, to encourage this Assembly to openly confront the issue.
It appears that there is no intention to address the topic.
I wonder, and I ask you, honorable colleagues from all political groups, if not on these issues, on what other matters should the political war of the peoples of Europe be waged?
Thank you, President. Concluding the negotiation with Croatia by 2010 is an achievable goal, and the Svoboda report aptly highlights the progress made and the steps still to be taken.
Now it is the justice sector that still requires significant reforms.
It is not enough, in fact, to complete the necessary systemic reforms, enact new laws, and cooperate as needed with the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia.
I insist on the need to create a genuine legal culture and mindset in line with European standards.

The independence of the judiciary becomes crucial, along with central issues such as training, recruitment, and the career progression of judges. It is essential to ensure the absence of various types of influence exerted by the government over the judiciary.
I appeal to the Commission to consider the necessity of decisive measures in this regard during the final phase of the negotiation.

Thank you, President. Croatia's accession to the European Union strengthens the consolidation of a European identity, capable of expressing the common values of the new Europe without eclipsing, but rather integrating the specific characteristics of its many facets.

The Republic of Croatia has made commendable efforts in aligning itself with the required parameters, particularly in combating organized crime through new anti-mafia measures. However, it needs to make further efforts, especially in the judicial sector, before the 2010 negotiations can be concluded.

Further steps can be taken by the institutions of the Republic of Croatia to align with the provisions of the first protocol of the European Convention on Human Rights, signed in Paris in 1952, by considering the restitution of nationalized property to its legitimate owners.

We firmly wish to tell the Commission and the Council that the European Union, which has raised the flag of the fight against atmospheric emissions and the climate challenge before the world, today has the duty of consistency, if it does not want to lose credibility.
You must do everything possible to ensure these goals are achieved.

We must be very well aware that talking about a low-emission economy means a kind of Copernican revolution for the productive system. It means changing many things, having clear priorities, political will, but above all, adequate resources and tools.
We also know that this Copernican revolution is essential if our productive system, European industry, is to remain competitive.
I mean that in many countries, in many research centers, in many universities, the intelligences are ready, the abilities are there, the will is present, now it is a matter of igniting this engine.
Everyone must do this, said the Commissioner, said the Council. Member States, entrepreneurs, and private entities must do this.
but I believe that the indispensable task of bringing together this complex partnership lies with the European Union.
To constructively address the employment issue, there are three key principles of community engagement. React, evolve, and protect.

React, that is, move away from the celebratory tones of Europropaganda to tackle in a concrete way the problems afflicting EU citizens, ensuring a direct link between the world of education and the needs of the market and the territory, and improving young people's perception of manual professions.

To evolve, that is, to make the EU 2020 strategy a positive synthesis between the demands of businesses and those of workers, in favor of a labor market where the flexibility and security of contractual forms respond to the instabilities of market demand.

To protect, that is, to provide jobs for those who have lost them, first and foremost among our own citizens. Member States must therefore assess immigration policies based on the actual needs for immigration. With 23 million unemployed, the possibility of suspending extracomunity immigration for a few years should be considered.
I see no other way to protect our work and our social system.
What is needed is practicality, courage, and decentralization.

Yes, President, I would like to emphasize once again the importance of the written declaration on corruption that I proposed together with four other members of parliament and which more than half of the European Parliament has approved, in order to commit the Council and the Commission to truly effective legislation on corruption.

I have returned on behalf of the Budget Control Commission from a visit to Greece, and certainly one of the reasons for Greece's structural crisis also stems from the waste of public funds, a situation that also occurs in Italy.

Corruption is eroded by corruption, as is emerging these days, corruption that primarily circulates through the illegal management of public funds, the relationship between a part of the political sphere and a part of entrepreneurs, and the organized white-collar criminality.

It is important that the European Parliament exert all its pressure on the Commission and the Member States, that those Member States that do not comply be sanctioned, and that the European institutions responsible for controlling corruption and combating organized crime be strengthened.

To solve this problem, I believe it is necessary to implement measures, such as those contained in the directive we are discussing, while keeping our gaze firmly fixed on the polar star of the family. Only this can give meaning and hope of success to these very measures.

Thank you, Mr. President. Honourable colleagues, as we know, the European Parliament has been called to express its final opinion on food information to consumers.
It must be stated at the outset that this was an objectively arduous, lengthy, and contentious legislative process, which could not be shortened.

The aim is indeed to harmonize Community law on food through regulations that ensure transparent consumer information, thus preventing them from making confused or potentially harmful choices, even with regard to their health.

The delegation of Honorable Sommer, whose efforts to synthesize multiple requirements should be acknowledged, aims to rectify the controversial and varying information systems currently in place across the countries of the Union.

It is no coincidence that national regulations to this day differ in the designations of the nature of foods placed on the market, creating a system that varies from country to country and also fueling unfair competition to the detriment of potential consumers.
Thus, based on the proposal of the European Commission, an attempt has been made to give a new form to the existing legislation, involving food industries on one hand and consumers on the other.
Simultaneously, the regulation commits the European food industry to clarify the mandatory indications and the presentation of nutritional and nutritional values.

In a globalized market, the European Union could not exempt itself from updating its food legislation through innovation, in order to better protect the food trade as well, safeguarding it from increasingly invasive and cutthroat international competition.

It is not new to hear more and more about the perversity of food products, about surreptitious and misleading indications on labels that often do not meet dietary requirements, yet are still marketed as food and beneficial for human health.

Thank you, President. The proposal on the rights of bus passengers aims to enhance and safeguard passenger protection, especially for persons with disabilities or reduced mobility.
This is the first regulation on the rights of bus passengers and should provide guarantees for passengers, as is already the case in the rail and air sectors.
The position in the second reading aims to establish a series of rights for passengers who decide to travel by bus,

I agree with the approach of rapporteur Cancian, whom I thank for the excellent work done, and I believe that the scope of the regulation should be amended to exclude regional services when they are integrated with urban and suburban services.
It would be fair and necessary to ensure the rights of passengers in the event of accidents, cancellations, or delays at departure, as had already been decided by the Parliament in its first reading.

Equally important is the issue of information on passenger rights. In fact, it would be useful to provide passengers with information on connections with other modes of transport. This will also ensure dialogue between passenger transport services by bus and by rail.

As for people with disabilities and reduced mobility, it is necessary to ensure the highest level of protection. I would propose reducing the time frame from 48 hours to 24 hours to request assistance, as well as stronger guarantees for compensation and replacement of the tools that ensure the mobility of people with disabilities in case of loss or damage.
Furthermore, taking into account the needs of passengers with reduced mobility, any architectural barriers should be removed and existing infrastructure improved to make it accessible.
This regulation aims to enhance the competitiveness of the bus sector, promote intermodality, but above all, to improve passenger travel conditions.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to express my gratitude to rapporteur Sterks, who has done an excellent job on this report, which addresses how to extend free movement in the maritime sector for navigation within the European Union.
I share the rapporteur's objective for this directive, which is to exempt all maritime freight transport within the European Union from unnecessary administrative formalities.

In fact, to achieve a European maritime space without borders, it is not only important that the various competent authorities cooperate satisfactorily, but also that the various simplification systems be applied simultaneously.
This is necessary to ensure the smooth functioning of the entire European maritime space without borders, to make sea freight transport more attractive and to optimize its use.

Harmonizing administrative procedures among Member States will enable smoother navigation between the various ports of the European Union and boost maritime freight traffic, which currently accounts for less than 10% of the total.
To date, navigation continues to be hindered by the administrative formalities imposed upon it.
Electronic systems should therefore be brought into operation as quickly as possible, as this would allow for a faster data exchange system.

Furthermore, interoperability is crucial for achieving genuine administrative simplification. Indeed, the transmission of information via email is not fully efficient and proves useless if information systems are not technically interoperable.
As for language, I believe that the use of a common language would undoubtedly benefit European maritime navigation.
In this way, communication would be more efficient, causing less confusion and reducing administrative delays.

Yes, thank you, Mr. President. Firstly, I would like to congratulate our rapporteur, Hon. Kramer, in particular, because we all know that we have truly achieved a result that sometimes seemed unlikely.

However, I am here this evening to state with conviction that, in my opinion, we have achieved the best possible outcome in terms of protecting competition, the environment, and European industrial and employment policy.
We have, on the one hand, a directive that imposes common obligations on all Member States, but on the other hand, a directive that also allows for the flexibility that is necessary.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, Mr. Commissioner, with this measure, we aim to strengthen and rationalize the pharmacovigilance system of the European Union.
These are the ambitious objectives set out in the Meccheva relations, which respectively amend Regulation 726 and Directive 2183.
Thanks to a process of close and efficient cooperation between the Council and the European Parliament, as well as the relevant parliamentary committees, it has been possible
to discuss today a proposal aimed at enhancing the Community pharmacovigilance system and refining the substantial and long-standing activity of the European Union in this field.

Simplification, transparency, and rationalization can be considered the key points of these two reports, which propose measures aimed at ensuring the best possible protection of public health based on harmonized standards across Europe.

Indeed, reference is made to a wide range of interventions that span from a better definition of roles and responsibilities of the main national and supranational stakeholders involved, to a new and more consciously active engagement of the patient, to whom we

recognizes a fundamental actor role within the system in strengthening the transparency of information regarding medication safety, in simplifying communication activities, and in the registration and evaluation of reported adverse drug reactions.
The current pharmacovigilance system needs to be improved, also through closer collaboration at the European, national, and regional levels.
Effective participation at all three of these levels will indeed ensure a fruitful exchange of information regarding the side effects of medications.
The new pharmacovigilance system will be able to provide a high level of shared and secure information for the benefit of patients, national authorities, and healthcare professionals.

Thank you, Mr. President. Just in these past few days here in Brussels, several events have taken place that... [Note: The sentence appears to be incomplete in the provided Italian text, so I've maintained that structure in the translation.]

Many representatives from municipalities and regions discussed how to tackle the serious problems affecting the lives of our cities, the old and new needs that impact workers, families, and small and large productive businesses.
The economic crisis that has struck our societies has made it harder and more challenging for all of us to provide adequate responses to a new, serious social issue.
In this context, I believe that everyone has understood that the cohesion policy has been, on many occasions, the only concrete tool available to the regions to try to provide responses.
Therefore, we can say that the cohesion policy has been, in recent years, an essential lever for the process of European integration for all regions.
Now we find ourselves redefining this policy for the post-2013 period. We are, therefore, at a turning point.
For this reason, it is vital to avoid certain risks.
The first fundamental aspect is the need for its renationalization. This would be a significant step backward.

Then, in drawing up the financing budget, it is necessary to ensure an adequate request both for the weaker realities and, at the same time, for the ability not to penalize the most competitive and advanced regions.
Finally, it is essential to simplify procedures for those who have proven to be efficient and to strengthen the ability to sanction those who have not been.
We expect the Commission to move in this direction.
Honorable colleagues, the path towards a Europe that is inclusive and supportive of women is still long and challenging.
The statistics are unequivocal. The global crisis has hit the labor market hard, severely impacting women's employment, which further decreased by seven-tenths of a percentage point in 2008.

Despite the provocations regarding equal opportunities and employment that periodically fill a declining pro-European propaganda, to date, no concrete measures have been adopted to ensure women genuine fulfillment as workers and as mothers.
The Europe of the future needs to radically rethink its welfare model rather than merely changing its label periodically.

Therefore, the decision to align the Institute of Maternity Leave in Europe is positive, but it is inefficient to address the complementary and equally important matter of paternity leave only marginally in the same report.

The greater integration of women is not only a moral value but also a strategic objective for the sustainability of the much-touted European social model, which continues to fail to convince me due to its lack of results.
Thank you, I will begin. Thank you, Mr. President. The rapporteur for the Development Committee, Mr. Mitchell, has asked me to stand in for him as he is unable to attend today.

In the course of 2009, the European Commission presented a proposal to amend Regulation 1905 of 2006, establishing a financial instrument for development cooperation.
With this proposal, the Commission had requested that Parliament approve an amendment allowing non-governmental organizations to benefit from tax advantages when operating in developing countries.
proposal accepted by us.
But the Cooperation and Development Regulation also contains the implementing rules for the European Union's development policy.
These regulations stipulate that whenever the Commission is to allocate funding, it must adhere to the comitology procedures.

This means that the Parliament has the power to scrutinize this funding proposal, and in the event that the Commission exceeds its powers, the Parliament can then adopt resolutions to request that the Commission change the decisions in question.

Only from 2006 to present has the Parliament deemed that in at least 12 cases the Commission had exceeded its implementing powers, but in only three of these cases did the Commission actually amend or withdraw its proposal for a decision.
Following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the Development Committee proposed to apply the procedure for delegated acts as provided for in Article 290 of the Treaty of Lisbon.
The adoption of these procedures would mean that, at least in the strategic funding decisions that the European Commission must adopt, Parliament would play a more significant role.
In fact, according to the Treaty of Lisbon, in certain well-defined cases, the Parliament can delegate to the Commission the power to make strategic decisions. But what might these decisions be?
In our view, the choice of countries to which the European Union should provide development aid
This is a decision for the legislature. So, which sectors should then be prioritized for funding? Education? Health? Environmental protection? Good governance capacity? Small business development?
And how can transparency be ensured in the management of development aid?
These are the choices, the areas in which the European Parliament should play a more significant role than it has in the past.
It is here that the legislator must provide precise indications to the executive.
And it is precisely in this direction that, I believe, the demands of European citizens ultimately lie.
I truly hope for the widest possible consensus on this report by Hon. Mitchell.

and perhaps not even that, but only an attempt at compensation through a 100% reduction in European industrial emissions by the same year, by 2020.

Thank you, President. Currently, access to employment is regulated only for certain specific categories of citizens from third countries.
In fact, not everyone benefits from the general principle of equal treatment in access to employment.

In this context, the European Union must act to ensure fair treatment for both third-country nationals legally residing within Member States and beneficiaries of refugee status or those in need of international protection, as per Directive 83 of 29 April 2004.

It is necessary to prevent a growing demand, for example, for seasonal staff solely because they are paid less or because they have different, lower costs compared to a European citizen recruited for the same job.

One must avoid, for instance, the risk that many multinationals relocate their headquarters to countries like Morocco or Turkey and send their employees to work in European branches because it is cheaper.
For reasons of social justice, ensuring the same treatment of European citizens in terms of remuneration, working conditions, and social security is fundamental.
For this reason, I believe it is right that seasonal workers, posted workers, refugees, and self-employed workers are included in this directive.
Making differences will become extremely dangerous.

Thank you, Mr. President. Honourable colleagues, human trafficking, according to estimates by international organizations and law enforcement agencies, is now the second-largest source of profit globally for organized crime, after drug trafficking.
It is estimated that approximately 30 million people are victims of organ trafficking, prostitution, and forced labor.
This means that, above all, the fight against this criminal phenomenon of vast proportions is a battle for the safety of our citizens, against clandestinity, and against the crime that breeds crime.
In the face of a phenomenon of this magnitude, Europe must rightly implement drastic measures against those who exploit human beings in various forms.

In combating this phenomenon, cooperation between Member States and between law enforcement agencies is necessary, but above all, there must be certainty of punishment for traffickers. However, let us remember that many people are discovered.

exploited because in their countries of origin they do not find dignified living conditions, they live in poverty and despair, and they are willing to do anything to leave their homeland for the promise of a better life that will not be fulfilled.

acceptable. Let us help them in their own countries. This must be the guiding principle of European political action so that our efforts are directed not only towards repression but also towards prevention.

Thank you, President. The situation is that Campania, and in particular the city of Naples, unfortunately now live universally under the gaze of the entire world at night, and the European Union has had to address the issue on several occasions.

Facing such a paradoxical, Third World-like situation, I therefore ask the Commission what consequences Italy will face from the perspective of Community law, and what economic sanctions may potentially be imposed on Italy if the waste crisis in the countryside does not find a definitive solution in the short term.

I further ask whether the Commission can provide in detail the data concerning the European funds that have so far been managed by the Region of Campania for the creation of an integrated waste collection and disposal system.
You see, Commissioner, usually when we speak of an emergency, we refer to dramatic, extreme situations that, nonetheless, find a solution within reasonable timeframes.
When a so-called emergency has lasted for over 15 years, clearly something is not working.

The Italian government in recent years has endeavored to do everything possible to resolve the long-standing issue of waste collection and disposal cycles. But evidently, if today the streets of Naples are overrun with tons of waste,
Tons of garbage, the fault is primarily attributable to the local authorities, who have shown a total incapacity or lack of will to work towards finding a solution.

It is clear, and absolutely beyond any doubt, that the conditions affecting Naples and Campania are due to the absence of effective management that has characterized municipalities, provinces, and regions for many years in the handling of waste management.
If due attention is not paid to separate collection, an indispensable first element of a functioning waste management plan, it cannot be the fault of the Central Government.

If the Italian Government has had to send in the army, as happened a few weeks ago, and on other occasions previously, to replace hundreds of garbage collectors who suddenly and simultaneously fell ill, it cannot evidently be the fault of the Central Government.

If the emergency has hit Naples, while the situation is very different in the rest of Italy, for example in my region, Veneto, where the collection of referenced waste has been carried out for years without problems and with a very high recycling rate, it means that the responsibilities for the emergency fall on specific entities.

The method we are employing is an artifice, for which we are grateful to Mr Fraga, namely that of an oral question to discuss something that, following the Treaty of Lisbon, should instead be a right of this Parliament.

Thank you, Mr. President. Until today, the recommendations adopted by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean have been provisionally incorporated into Community legislation through annual regulations on fishing opportunities.
These pertain to the conservation measures, management, exploitation, control, and commercialization for fishery products and aquaculture in the Mediterranean.
The permanent nature of this recommendation, however, requires a more stable legal instrument for their incorporation into Community law.
It is therefore appropriate to incorporate the aforementioned recommendations through a single legislative act, to which future recommendations may be added.
Today we have done this, and this will improve legal certainty while also constituting an important step towards simplification.
At this point, the contracting parties of the CGMPM are obligated to ensure the full implementation of the agreed measures, starting from high stability.

A timely transposition was therefore necessary in order to make these international measures directly applicable to natural or legal persons at Community level and to ensure legal certainty for those concerned.
Mr. President, I believe that the adoption of Ms. Podima's report represents a significant step forward towards a more balanced, advanced, and robust economic and fiscal policy in the European arena.

It is now evident to all the urgency of equipping ourselves, as Europe, as a coordination between the 27 countries, with economic and financial tools capable of governing the economy and not just enduring it.

The fact that the majority of this Parliament voted for this regulation is an important and significant development, because for the first time, inaction was not an option, and instead, a step forward was taken.
I hope that the Commission and the Council continue on this path.

Thank you, Mr. President. Thanks to the Treaty of Amsterdam, environmental policy and sustainability policy have gained greater importance and the
Attention has focused on the integration of economic policy with environmental policy and on incorporating environmental issues into policies and other sectors.

Key sectors include climate change, sustainable transport, nature, biodiversity, health and the environment, as well as the use of natural resources and waste management, along with the international dimension of sustainable development.
In June 2006, the European Council, in its conclusions, called on the Union and its Member States to extend national accounts to the key aspects of sustainable development.
National accounts should therefore be supplemented by an integrated economic and environmental accounting system, capable of providing fully consistent data.
I voted in favor of this regulation proposal because it creates new uses for national accounting data and environmental statistics and for other statistical sectors.

Thank you, President. My favorable vote on the Garriga report on the Union's upcoming financial perspectives stems from the conviction that it is precisely in one of the most critical moments that we must define a clear strategic vision for the future.
It is crucial for the so-called European spirit to insist on and prevail in the indispensability of providing credible tools, starting from an adequate financial endowment for the Union.

Therefore, the request for a 5% increase in the next budget is a fair and necessary request, perhaps not sufficient, but indispensable to provide answers to the great questions before us. In fact, these resources are needed for

addressing real issues, such as stronger cohesion among the Regions, greater research and innovation capacity, and a stronger ability to generate growth and provide employment. Indeed, without resources

unless adequate solutions are found for each of these issues. Starting with the introduction of this intermediate category in cohesion policy, which only makes sense if it does not harm the other existing categories.
This is why I voted in favor, and I hope that the Commission and the Council will follow the guidelines set out in this report.

Thank you, Mr. President. The new Hungarian Constitution reduces the intervention possibilities of oversight bodies such as the Constitutional Court and increases the powers of the executive, thus challenging the normal balance of powers.
Social rights are eroded, the state provides subsidies to the needy only if they agree to perform community service.
Lastly, the right to self-defense is established, which allows individuals to possess weapons in their homes even without a license.
The right to abortion is prohibited, and severely discriminatory rules towards homosexuals are introduced.
All of this is contrary to Directive 78-2000, which establishes a general framework for combating discrimination.

I therefore ask the Commissioner how she intends to act, considering that the fundamental rights of the new Hungarian Constitution are poorly compatible with those of the European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.

starting with the request for coherence between objectives and instruments, between the new role that European institutions are called upon to play after Lisbon and in the face of recession, and the resources that we collectively decide to invest.

it tells us that cohesion is today a vital node of the European project, an important heritage for all, to be safeguarded, protected, and renewed.

risk and speculation. When we reach the point, as has happened, of trading and insuring $400 million without collaterals, that is, without adequate reserves, we understand the risks we are taking.

Having said that, however, I would also like to touch upon two issues. The first issue concerns our relationship with the Council. The second issue pertains to the coherence of the proposal for the reform of financial markets that we need to pursue.

I raise the first issue concerning the Council, and I do so in a very clear manner. The perception is all too often that the Council represents an obstacle to acting quickly and effectively on the reform of financial markets.
I hope that the new Presidency will take up this issue, because even on this occasion we must contribute to the debate with concrete proposals.
