It is a problem that also concerns the procedure we wish to follow.
The second issue concerns the organic nature and specificity of the measures.
There is not only the measure on OTCs, there is the measure on short selling and other measures.

I wish to highlight two points. The specific issue of the raw materials market, a particular market requiring specific anti-speculative measures, and the problem of local authorities' exposure to derivatives in the countries of the European Union.
I believe these are issues that Parliament must address.
Thank you, President. The Fukushima accident continues to produce very serious consequences with the loss of radioactive water into the sea, 6,500 times above legal limits.
The risk of food products becoming contaminated is high.
Europe has established very strict controls, but this concerns only fresh produce.
No protective regulations have been issued for processed products, particularly canned fish.
We import 370,000 tons of canned tuna. The main suppliers are Southeast Asian countries, which import fish from Japan.
This means that canned fish imported into Europe may contain Japanese fish.
It is fundamental and urgent to provide precise information about the place of origin.
Today, in fact, consumers know where the box was produced, but not the location where the fish was caught.

The Commission has recently acknowledged this and plans to address this gap through the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy, which, however, will not enter into force for at least two years, just as the Sommer report under discussion in this plenary will not take effect for three years.
We must not create alarmism, but consumers have the right to urgent and transparent information,
The Commission must intervene as soon as possible.
Mr. President Tusk, your speech gives us great hope. The hope is that the Polish presidency will be a contribution to the fight against an Europe of national egoisms.
nationalistic, with no vision for the future, but rather a contribution in favor of Europe, which truly thinks of itself as an integrated reality with a shared destiny.
But, as she rightly pointed out in her speech, a Presidency faces concrete problems that need to be addressed and resolved.
In this brief time, I wish to draw your attention to two crucial issues on the front of the economic-financial crisis.
First issue. The reform of financial markets.

This is not a technical issue, it is a major democratic matter of our time. The timelines are too long. We need to resolve issues such as the reform of short selling and over-the-counter (OTC) transactions.
Second point. We are faced with the issue of taxing financial transactions. We need to delve into the specifics. We expect the Polish Presidency to provide a concrete contribution in this regard.
It has been more than twenty years since the signing of the Schengen agreements.
No one questions the benefits of free movement, but it must be acknowledged that the current arrangement is no longer adequate for present and future needs.

For this reason, all Member States must commit to reviewing the functioning mechanisms of Schengen, so that the freedom of movement does not come at the expense of the legitimate security concerns of our citizens.

As far as we know so far, the Commission's guidelines may also be partly acceptable, especially regarding the introduction of a mechanism that allows states to temporarily re-establish border controls in case of emergency.
We must see, however, how this will happen and whether the statements will be followed by actions and, above all, by tangible results.

Certainly, it will also be necessary to address the general reform of the European border protection system, especially its external borders. Frontex must become, as soon as possible, an agency with real powers of intervention and support for national authorities.
We must protect our external borders if we wish to continue with this Schengen agreement.
It is time for courageous choices in this Europe if one does not wish to merely survive.

The crisis has deeply marked the real lives of European citizens and businesses, and risks, if we do not react, irreversibly lowering the social and cultural quality, well-being, and future of young people and Europeans.

nothing less than cohesion and prosperity values. Getting out of the crisis means creating remedies for the identified causes, remedies against speculation, which, if necessary, must also be cut down to size, by imposing strict rules on financial markets, remedies

against the recession, remedies against an unbalanced development model that has placed the person a step below profit, remedies against resurgent nationalism, which does indeed prevent Europe from making the choices that are rightfully theirs today.

Above all, it is time to define the tools, resources, even new ones, to move forward, to ignite the engines of growth, through research, innovation, training, and support for productive investments, infrastructure, and labor. Because without work, people are without dignity and without rights.
This report, thanks to Pervance, Beressa, and colleagues, outlines a possible strategy for a Europe proud and aware of its role.
to European leadership. If they exist, it is now up to them to take responsibility for implementing it.

But Europe will not be credible to its citizens if it does not learn to be consistent. And we here wish to be consistent in this Parliament and at this stage in Europe's life.

And so, if we say that we want to base the union on values, on human rights, I do not believe we can so drastically interrupt or cut a program for those who do not eat, in other words, for those who do not have the right to food, to access to food, and family rights.

fundamental for an unresolved legal issue. It is an agricultural fund, it is a social fund, and if it is to be social, Commissioner, it should not be at the expense of other social programs, but rather a new, ad hoc fund with appropriate resources.
We say we want to ensure food security for Europeans, but the primary right to security is to have food, and then for it to be healthy.
So, here is our consistency and our commitment.
Let us then find a legal solution that ensures continuity and, with the help of non-governmental volunteer organizations, guarantees the first fundamental human right, that to C.
Only to support this relation and emphasize two aspects in particular. One, because it inserts itself into the debate currently underway on...
revision of the common fisheries policy and on the underlying option which is linked to the regionalization of a policy that, having been centralized in recent years, has shown all its weaknesses.
This phase of regionalization finds a particular application in the Black Sea.

I believe that the elements contained in Ms. Iotova's report describe a particular, but repeatable, situation across the rest of Europe. The situation in the Adriatic Sea in the Kingdom is no different.

In the Tyrrhenian Sea or the Geo Sea? That is, the interactions, especially between European fishing and non-European fishing, so to speak, are often very harmful to European markets and European consumers.
The second issue I would like to briefly highlight is the call for a common coastal guard.
There is no politics without the exercise of control.

Checks and controls today are carried out by disparate forces across Europe. I believe it is time to understand how one of the first European law enforcement agencies, namely the coast guards, could have a common management, greater coordination, and why not, a single European corps.
Here, with this hope, I fully support the contents of the report by colleague Iotova.
Thank you, Mr. President. The disaster that struck the Gulf of Mexico over a year ago prompted the European Commission to reflect on legislation related to offshore oil platform activities.
The European Parliament, through this report, also sought to express its position on the matter, adopting a text that requires adequate technical and financial capacities.
to industry operators and aims to establish high safety standards to lead the European Union in promoting the safety of offshore activities.
The new measures in this field requested of the Commission must focus on international coordination and a realistic approach that combines all existing excellences.
in the sector, at the level of procedures and debts, the creation of new bodies or additional bureaucracy that could risk diverting from the achievement of concrete final objectives.

The report, in concrete terms, in addition to holding operator companies more accountable, calls for the improvement of communication mechanisms and the sharing of information and knowledge. It also advocates for the strengthening and expansion of the role and expertise of the European Maritime Safety Agency.
It is for all these reasons that I consider the result achieved to be positive, thanks to the enrichment of this text to which we have expressed our support.
I would like to thank colleagues Zeber and Schilakakis, as well as Commissioner Edegard.

I believe that we are here today discussing and reasoning in order to truly achieve a strong European climate policy, capable of safeguarding economic development and the well-being of European citizens.
International climate policies, as has been recalled thus far, have primarily focused on reducing CO2 emissions.
the proposal highlights how we must also tackle the fight against other anthropogenic emissions that cause the formation of tropospheric ozone, impacting climate change.

Many things have already been mentioned that I believe we should keep in mind. Today, we are able to do this at absolutely reasonable costs; we have the technologies available, and although it is questionable, it is the CO2 emissions that primarily have an impact.

And while it is undeniable that the other greenhouse gases present in the atmosphere are in much smaller percentages, there is no doubt that their potential is very high and that, therefore, we could truly achieve significant and very important results in just a few years, in a few decades.
important

there are many points of contact with the analysis carried out by the colleagues, and therefore I imagine that these too will be aspects that will allow Europe to present itself to Urban with an even stronger, more concrete, and significant position.

I will only add, as has already been mentioned, that given the extraordinarily challenging and sensitive moment we are experiencing, we were just discussing the homeless a few minutes ago, there is a heightened sensitivity among European citizens that we must take into account. Therefore, considering the great sensitivity...

Sensitivity, of course, should be our top priority. Regarding jobs, we should also be able to launch a communication campaign that clearly explains to citizens our concrete plans for development, their well-being, and the protection of jobs. Thank you.
The single market, free movement, the Lisbon Treaty are all elements that have intervened regardless of a change in our way of legislating, in the European way, and in the national way.

It is necessary to follow up on the commitments that have arisen from these opportunities. In particular, it is necessary to genuinely initiate a phase of simplification of the legislative system. A simplification phase that must lead to a different dialogue between Europe and individual states.

I would start precisely with our documents. I take the opportunity to suggest a kind of clarity test for our documents. When we produce a white paper, a green paper, it must be more understandable. I go so far as to say that the real and perhaps strategic proposal for our Europe and to truly launch this...

this virtuous stage of legislative initiation is to assign a specific mandate to a European Commissioner who will specifically focus on clarifying legislation and relations between states and Europe itself.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, representative of the Council, and Commissioner, first of all, I would also like to warmly welcome, as other colleagues have done, the anti-corruption package approved by the European Commission on June 6th.
Corruption is a transnational phenomenon and measures at the European level are necessary to combat it.
The vast majority of our European citizens, according to Eurobarometer estimates, believe that Europe should do more.
How can one fault them?

In many Member States, there has been a lack of political will to combat corruption. Consider that there are still European countries that have not signed the United Nations Convention against Corruption.

When we consider the devastating impact of corruption on democratic processes, citizens' rights, and trust in the rule of law, it is clear that the national measures to combat it, adopted so far by the Member States, are insufficient to contain a phenomenon that is on the rise.

It is the European Union that must provide a unified and strong response, especially now, in the midst of an unprecedented economic crisis, which is impacting the lives of people, the resilience of pension and welfare systems, and the ability of institutions to ensure essential services.
Corruption results in the loss of 120 billion euros annually, equivalent to 1% of the European Union's GDP, and daily diverts resources from the Union and its Member States.
could be used to provide essential services, instructions, childcare, employment, transportation, in short, to divert clean resources towards supporting people.

Therefore, it is necessary to show more courage and firmness, both by monitoring the implementation of anti-corruption measures and by stepping up and strengthening the measures to combat corruption at EU level.

In particular, we cannot speak of fighting corruption if we are unable to adopt at least minimum rules for the definition of the crime of corruption, of which there is no trace in the recently approved package.
The same applies to the definition of uniform parameters for measuring the extent of the phenomenon in the Member States, essential for developing an effective response.
We are in favor, for example, of revitalizing the network of contact points between the two institutions to combat corruption, as I proposed in the resolution we will vote on tomorrow.
The crisis is not of recent origin; it has been ongoing for several years.
Perhaps it is time for a critical assessment of the policies followed so far. Has everything always been done well?
We have always conducted appropriate situational analyses.
Has the right approach been chosen?
The same European Central Bank, which, as Minister Rostovski says, saved Europe, has always done well even when, fearing inflation, it raised interest rates.
President Barroso identifies a problem: the speed of markets and the slowness of politics. But is this the only problem?

Certainly, if we consider that we are still operating under the implementation of July 21, this should at least suggest the need to better prepare and organize summits and their conclusions. However, politics will always be slower than markets.
The point is to look further ahead, shifting the focus to unemployment reduction and development.
This is the path that the European Commission must choose. Even today, in President Barroso's speech, there was more concreteness on the deficit and less on indications of growth and development.

The Commission should overcome its weakness, state that the priority is fighting unemployment and creating jobs, redistributing wealth, and implementing a strategy of public investments, also changing the rules of the new European stability pact.
Mr. President, I believe that the challenge for the coming years is to ensure that Europe, as has been said, retains its leading position of the highest order.
a global tourist destination and at the same time capable of enhancing, in terms of both environmental protection and competitive capacity, its entire territorial heritage.

It is a challenging and non-trivial task, especially in light not only of the opportunities, but also of the aggressiveness of other countries in this sector, from other continents, from China to India to Brazil.
Now, in this context, as Commissioner Tajani recalled, it becomes fundamental, as also noted in the Commission's opinion that we approved in the Regional Development Committee,
maintain a strong overall strategy for the entire European Union on tourism, while enhancing the role of regions and territories.
In this sense, it is essential to fully engage, from the outset, while respecting the principle of subsidiarity of the Regions and local authorities.
Furthermore, I believe that the development of integrated tourist networks and projects should be encouraged, starting with the creation of partnerships for the exchange of best practices.
It also seems right to me to propose the identification of an 'Europe brand' that is able to define a high quality of the tourist product.
Obviously, it will be up to the Commission to better define the priorities, especially from a financial standpoint, to ensure that this European primacy is maintained in the future.
President, the preparation of the common strategic framework for funding research and innovation constitutes one of the greatest opportunities that European development and economy have before them.

In fact, it is a matter of acting on the lever that can truly trigger a moment of growth and also of new qualified employment, such as that of researchers and young people who dedicate themselves precisely to the new opportunities for innovation, technology, and related professions.
One observation that particularly stands out from this work is that we must increasingly emphasize in Europe a research and innovation that leads to practical application, that results in...
to give birth to new businesses, which lead to new patents and do not remain purely basic research, pure knowledgeimportant though it isbut rather trigger the real bubble of development.

The second observation concerns the relationship with local authorities, regions, and territories, which are also an important tool for territorial programming and for the interaction between research, universities, centers of excellence, and businesses.

Thank you, President. European Schools were established with the aim of ensuring access to education in their mother tongue for the children of European institutional staff who are called upon to work and live abroad in a cultural context different from that of their home country.
The first European school was established in Luxembourg in the distant year of 1953 at the initiative of a group of officials.
Over the years, given the positivity of this form of teaching, as many as 14 European schools have been established within the various Member States.

While acknowledging that the system of European schools represents a necessity rather than a luxury, it is evident that, more than 50 years after the creation of the first European school, this system may present outdated aspects and must in some way be updated and adapted to meet the new economic and social needs of Europe.

I therefore expressed my vote in favor of the text by colleague Cavada, which aspires to greater involvement by the European Union to support and coordinate the actions of the Member States, called upon to work to develop and improve the system of European schools.
And investing, as we know, investing in education means investing in the future of our young Europeans. Thank you, President.
Thank you, Mr. President. In recent decades, the number of natural disasters has increased exponentially, causing the deaths of tens of thousands of people in various parts of the world.
Last year, within the Development Committee, I followed the work on the report on the European Union's disaster response capacity, in which it is
how much more needs to be done to ensure a coordinated response from the European Union in the face of the increasing number of earthquakes, floods, and tsunamis.
The European Union's response to the Haiti earthquake, for example, clearly demonstrated the complexity of existing tools and procedures.

Although the Member States and Community institutions acted promptly in terms of sending humanitarian aid, the management of the crisis raised a series of issues in terms of efficiency, coordination, and transparency.

Precisely for this reason, I have expressed a favorable vote for the text presented by my colleague Elisabetta Gardini, which aspires to greater efficiency in all stages of disaster management, and enhanced coordination.
between the parties involved and a simplification aimed at avoiding unnecessary overlap and time-wasting that could hinder the provision of rapid and effective aid.
Yes, it is merely a good initiative. I believe it will then be a matter of constructing a European policy towards tourism.
The European brand has a good intuition, but I would like to dwell on two issues. There is no sea or coastal tourism without a coastal planning policy.

I believe it is time for Europe, precisely to safeguard this important sector, to launch an initiative where the concept of the sea and the concept of the coast are not limited to a kind of urban planning that ends at the water's edge and does not comprehensively engage the sea.
I believe that an integrated policy in this direction is useful, and it will be necessary to build everything that lies behind the claims of rural tourism. Rural tourism can be...
an excellent source of income for disadvantaged areas, for regions where there is no longer any work, where it is important to prevent further depopulation and encourage human settlement.

Well, it is not enough to make mere statements; one should suggest to Europe and individual states to intervene on the tax lever. Doing tourism in rural areas might mean paying fewer taxes. Perhaps this is how a real opportunity can be built for the tourism resource and for those who live there.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to express my congratulations on the work done by Hon. Fidanza, which logically fits into the framework of actions.
undertaken and promoted at EU level in the field of tourism, following the Lisbon Treaty which granted the EU new competences for the tourism sector.
I endorse and wish to emphasize the statement regarding the importance of a unified Europe as a destination for certified and high-quality tourism, and the determination to pursue this path.

the same idea by translating it into actions at the level of structures, resource allocations, funding, and coordination of actions between the various levels of government in the countries of the Union.

An approach that should be valued and rewarded, given the sector in question and its implications in terms of the percentage of yarn produced, employment, and new opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises.
Businesses, with a focus on environmental protection and enhancement, are positioned to develop and thus respond to the main challenges of our time.
For all these reasons, I consider this report positive, an important signal in the direction of promoting a European policy for tourism.
Thank you, President, also for the recovery. Three small considerations. We need more Europe here as well.
I believe it is inevitable that on certain issues there is truly an attitude where not only is more Europe desired, but it is also constructed.
More Europe means, for example, beginning to truly think about a common road police force, with identical rules in terms of protection and security.
More Europe means having a European policy on education, not simply delegating it to individual nations, but rather constructing, for instance, a genuine educational policy.
In relation to schools, in relation to young people, and also in relation to higher-risk groups, such as motorcyclists mentioned a moment ago, but this could also include truck drivers.
More Europe means having common tools within the vehicles that improve safety conditions, anti-alcohol and anti-distraction devices.
I believe it is a timely strategy to be developed with the automotive companies and European vehicle manufacturing.
Here, I believe that if all this is framed within the conviction of a common policy, I truly think that perhaps conditions will improve.

Thank you, President. This report tackles a subject that is global food security. Global implies that this issue is not solely about world hunger in the poorest countries, but that the matter of food supply concerns all communities, including those in the most developed nations.

between some lines, such as the essential one of coherence between European policies and this goal of global food security, because we are an institution that preaches very well but often lacks consistency in its choices.
I merely want to highlight three titles of innovative lines that I believe we should further develop.
The first is food supply, which today is at risk due to price volatility caused by speculation on food products, which needs to be contained if not prevented, derivatives and so on.
Secondly, the issue of land grabbing, which I believe should be the subject of some form of treaty or negotiation, as democracy, as well as the survival of many peoples, is at risk.
thirdly, the coherence between energy supply and policies
We cannot, in order to produce new energy, prevent the production of food for the world's populations.

Caronna.
a purely political character, as I believe it is necessary to bring the major issue of food security back to the center of the initiative of the entire European Union.

agricultural products. It is a major issue that, if not addressed promptly and decisively, will become one of the main threats, if not the most significant threat, to stability, peace, and even democracy, as has been seen.

For this reason, I believe it is indispensable that the entire European Union, together with the Member States, make all necessary efforts, starting with appropriate economic investments, as indicated in the report, in this direction, to seriously address this great issue.
Greetings to the Commission. I must truly thank all those who have contributed over these weeks, over these months, to the production of this document that we are voting on in the Chamber today.
We worked, I must say, very well and a truly constructive debate developed.
The resolution proposal we are voting on today is the result of a truly collaborative effort and reflects the contributions of all political groups and the entire Parliament.

I believe that a very strong and shared sensitivity has developed on this issue, also because, we must remember, we live in an era that is truly characterized by an exponential increase in catastrophes.
The numbers, when viewed in their raw form, are very eloquent. The number of disasters worldwide has quintupled. If we consider that in 1975
In the past, 78 catastrophic events had been recorded, whereas today we are facing nearly 400 disastrous events per year.

In the last 20 years, unfortunately, the victims of these disasters have numbered 90,000, and over 29 million individuals have been affected by the disasters, while economic losses amount to 211 billion euros.
It is evident that we are facing phenomena of such magnitude that they demand a stronger response, a more effective response, and a truly robust commitment from us.
We all have in our minds the images of the earthquake in Haiti, the flood in Pakistan, what happened in Japan.
Europe itself experiences sudden floods, fires, and let us remember the ash cloud following the eruption of the Icelandic volcano, all occurring on its own territory every year.
There is no need to belabor the point in asserting the significance of the work being done here in Parliament, guided by two principles.
fundamental principles that serve as our guiding stars, the principle of solidarity, which is strengthened by the solidarity clause of the Treaty of Lisbon, and the principle of subsidiarity.
We are moving forward along these lines.

The intervention of the European Union has always been generous and effective in the past, as evidenced, I believe, by the tireless work of our Commissioner Georgieva. However, today we need to take a qualitative leap.
A qualitative leap that we are ready to make to move from an ad hoc response to one where the reaction...
is enhanced through the prior identification of existing resources in the Member States made available to the European Civil Protection Mechanism.
It is important to emphasize as well that for this qualitative leap and to transition from information sharing and emergency response to a role of planning, monitoring,

coordination, which we hope will play a fundamental role in services such as GMS, and I take this opportunity to also express the concern regarding the budget for these new technologies, which are essential.
We have emphasized the importance of communication with citizens, because this is another aspect that the Japanese experience has taught us greatly; it is never sufficient, never enough.
And we await the Commission's response, to which we request that it present the proposal on civil protection in legislative form as soon as possible.
Oppressed ethnic minorities, Christians forced to practice their faith in secret, priests brutally murdered while authorities turn a blind eye. Anti-Western foreign policythis is today's Turkey.
My party, the Northern League, has always been opposed to Turkey's entry into Europe, as it represents a potential Trojan horse for radical Islamism in our continent.
Today more than ever, we are convinced that the EU must bring an end to accession negotiations.
The inexorable threats that Turkey has directed towards Europe must receive an immediate response.
It is unacceptable for a third country to dictate to Europe what it should do.
Cyprus is a full member state of the EU and has the undisputable right to assume the rotating presidency.
Europe must send a clear signal and demonstrate its readiness to defend Cyprus by all means necessary in the face of Turkey's political and military arrogance and bullying.
Immediately suspend the accession negotiations and be prepared to also suspend trade relations.
President, we are witnessing a decisive moment for the future of the euro and, with it, for the entire European project.
To have this awareness would mean stepping away from a short-sighted logic that subordinates everything to an ideological pursuit of fiscal rigor.
We all want the accounts of the various States to be in order, we all want to reduce indebtedness.
However, it is clear that without an intelligent investment policy capable of revitalizing the economy, there will be no chance of growth.
The only clear outcome in this scenario is that, as always, the heaviest prices will be paid by the most vulnerable social classes.
For this reason, together with the group of Socialists and Democrats, we voted against this report.
Indeed, we are proceeding in a single direction, which is one of rigor without growtha direction that has proven to be wrong up until now.
The work done by colleague Ferrera on this report is highly appreciated.
In fact, out of the package of six legislative proposals dedicated to economic governance, only on this one did I and my group express a positive vote.

We did this because, among other things, a clause protecting social rights starting from collective bargaining was inserted, and furthermore, there is a strengthening of the Parliament's role in the adoption of delegated acts.

Thus, while it is not possible to alter the overall balance of the six-proposal package, this report undoubtedly represents a step forward, among other things, in establishing a surveillance system that takes fundamental rights into account.

And so, in this context, while maintaining that a vision, in our opinion, based solely on austerity policies does not yield positive results, this report certainly represents a positive note in contrast to the trend.

Honorable colleagues, Finland and the Netherlands have taken their seats in the Council for a very simple reason. Bulgaria and Romania are currently unable to ensure effective border control and are plagued by rampant corruption that involves the political class and organized crime.
It is not populist movements that express this view, but the airport in its 2010 report on organized crime.
There is no populist propaganda, but a serious security issue.

Should Bulgaria join the Schengen Area at this time, police and security agencies anticipate that Bulgarian borders, particularly maritime ones, would become an easy target for Turkish and Eastern European crime, and Bulgaria and Romania would become the crossroads for human and drug trafficking.

It is natural that some Member States have significant reservations about the actual capacity of Bulgaria and Romania to ensure effective border controls against organized crime and corruption, and it is therefore absolutely natural that they opposed their accession to the Schengen area.
Allowing this now means paving the way for transnational crime and creating a breach in European borders, precisely where there is immense migratory pressure from Turkey.
The reasons to oppose are many, and Europe cannot ignore them.
I therefore ask to know what the intentions of the Commission and the Council are regarding this sensitive issue, which, in my opinion, has so far been addressed with
and without taking into account the dangers that the entry of Bulgaria and Romania would entail, according to the competent bodies in matters of security and international crime.

In my view, the Commission and the Council should postpone the entry of these two countries into Schengen and only give their approval when there is reasonable certainty that the entry of Bulgaria and Romania will not have implications for the security of European citizens.

Thank you, President. The crisis in Europe is entangling the issues of public budgets and private capital in a vicious circle with those of the productivity of our businesses. And the specter of recession is indeed present.
If, therefore, the priority of SMEs is crucial, I call on the Commission to absolutely, together with the Parliament, ensure that our good principles are put into practice.
practice and that the legislative initiatives of the SBA, the Small Business Act, become concrete practice in the member states, with a high level of effectiveness and quality.

Consider, Commissioner, what could be achieved if all Member States were to anticipate the application of the directive against late payment? What a great advantage this would be for SMEs! However, while SME evidence is important, we are still at the methodological level.

Certainly, it is right to check whether, when we legislate, we do so in the genuine interest and to the benefit of small and medium-sized enterprises. However, we request that there be a great deal of consistency and tenacity, so to speak, in-depth work to create the framework of opportunities that you have outlined.
If we appreciate what is being done by the Commission as well, we are ready to support it with the budget and the other possibilities we have.
I'll say just one word about credit.
Let's have a clear conversation with the banks, I tell you, Commissioner, because we must support small and medium-sized enterprises.
Thank you, thank you Mr. President. I have expressed my favorable vote for the text of my colleague, Honorable Wallis.
While not prejudicing the usual avenues of access to justice, I am convinced that an alternative dispute resolution (ADR) represents a rapid and cost-effective alternative to legal proceedings.
In addition to being an effective tool for small and medium-sized enterprises, ADR can also have significant online growth for resolving minor disputes.

Through joint action with the Member States, it is therefore necessary to promote the creation of a harmonized legal framework that, by strengthening citizens' trust in the internal market, can contribute to stimulating the European economy.

President, honorable colleagues, the report concerning the provision for sectors placed on the market under the flexibility regime, for which we have expressed our favorable vote, was inspired by a measured and realistic approach that has...

materialized, on the one hand, in avoiding the establishment of unrealistic and impossible-to-meet requirements, and on the other, in providing for a so-called flexibility regime that is structured through the anticipation of temporal phases and corresponding quantitative limits.

allowed emissions, provides for the annual release onto the market of a predetermined number of tractors meeting specific characteristics, thus enabling the gradual alignment with the established standards over time without causing disruption to the affected productive and industrial sectors.

Honorable Tantarella, the work accomplished has been significant, successfully balancing the demands of the major challenges the European Union is facing during this period with the needs of environmental protection and the current economic crisis context.
Thank you, President. The current global economic crisis, even more severe than that of 1929, has caused unsustainable imbalances in international economies over the past few years.
Trade disparities among countries, financial markets lacking common regulations, and instability in banking systems are all potential threats to financial and economic stability.
This resolution, to which I express my support, urgently emphasizes informed citizenship, with rules and global economic coordination.

The economy requires a global governance system, open markets, high economic and social standards, more responsible monetary policy, and stricter supervisory policies. And decision-making bodies, international economic organizations, must be the key actors at the center of this new approach.

Europe, in particular, needs a transparent blocking mechanism to reduce exaggerated stabilities exacerbated by globalization and to ensure far-reaching reforms aimed at promoting growth and reducing the debt of individual states.
This is the commitment, and this resolution emphasizes it to all countries.

Thank you, Mr President. I voted in favour of the report by my honourable colleague Mrs Matera, which examines the situation of lone mothers, who today, as has already been mentioned, account for more than 5% of the population of the European Union.

The European Union therefore has a moral obligation to protect them, and the text adopted today supports those policies that can provide concrete help for these women, such as, as I know, facilitating access to
healthcare assistance, flexible work opportunities that allow for a balance between private and professional life, priority access to affordable housing, and special unemployment subsidies.
Only through the implementation of these measures can we address the needs of a category that is increasingly significant in all advanced and industrialized countries.
Thank you, President. The budget sets a few clear and important objectives within the framework of the EU 2020 strategy. For this, thanks to the rapporteurs.
It is crucial to focus on investments and not solely on the prudent maintenance of the budget.
The alternative would be to passively witness the speculative philosophy that characterizes our time.
We can no longer afford to pursue individual interests, but must finally represent a single, unified entity ready for dialogue.

I congratulate the commitments made on pilot projects and preparatory actions in heading 2, as well as the funding for the integrated maritime policy not being to the detriment of other initiatives and programs in the fisheries sector.

This will enable us to implement new policies for better management of marine resources through comprehensive research and data exchange on fish stocks, introducing innovative projects that can be used as best practices in other marine areas, starting from the Adriatic.

I conclude with a brief note, looking ahead to future debates on the CFP, and in particular regarding the fisheries fund, I hope that greater efforts will be made in the area of fisheries control, which is at the heart of the fight against illegal fishing but also forms the basis for rebuilding our tools.
that fish is considered a common good.
Thank you, Mr. President. The economic, financial, and social crisis we are experiencing has clearly highlighted several weaknesses in the European economic and social model.

I believe that one of the most representative and alarming figures of the current situation is the nearly 6 million jobs lost in the last three years. These numbers are set to increase as the situation unfolds, unless there is a swift and effective response.

The text by colleague Bastos emphasizes that in order to make tangible progress, there is a need for improved synergy between education, training, and the labor market, along with unified political action aimed at ensuring greater alignment between the demand and supply within this market.
For these reasons, Mr. President, I have cast my vote in favor.
I cast a favorable vote for what Hon. Angelilli presented because it addresses an issue that deeply concerns me as both a mother and a grandmother.
Protecting children from sexual exploitation, abuse, and the revolting world of child pornography means safeguarding our sons and daughters, and consequently, defending the most vulnerable.
Increased prevention, tougher criminal action against those who commit such offenses, and more careful protection of childrenthese are the key points of the document voted on today.

Thank you, thank you President. Phosphates present in domestic laundry detergents end up in water systems, rivers, streams, and European lakes.

Phosphorus causes an acceleration in the reproduction of various forms of life. Consequently, algae and other rapidly developing plant species proliferate excessively when there is an increase in phosphorus levels in an aquatic environment.
This excessive algae growth deprives other living organisms of oxygen, can also produce toxins by destroying aquatic plant species, thus reducing the quality of the water itself.

I therefore expressed my vote in favor of the text adopted today because, in order to purify Europe's water resources, it is desirable to reduce the amount of phosphorus that is released into the waters of our continent.

Mr. President, the European Union has produced an enormous quantity of laws and regulations to construct European law and has created the European area known as the Stockholm Plan.
There is a discrepancy between this corpus, this legislative monument, and the use made of it by citizens, which is numerically and proportionally very low.
On the other hand, national judges, the legal professionals of individual states, have grown up within the legal system of their own country and have received predominant training in this regard.
We believe that the true European judge is the national judge who changes their mindset and immerses themselves in the knowledge of European law.

For this reason, before discussing training, one must first address a comprehensive communication to citizens and legal professionals, so that they can become the bearers of this significant innovation and foster the willingness to utilize the benefits of this right.

But above all, it is a bottom-up movement that must be created in in-service training. One cannot teach as if to schoolchildren in the judicial training of adult and highly professionally qualified individuals.

Stimulating curiosity is essential when addressing one's own cases and connecting with fellow colleagues to find solutions, as Common Law and Civil Law are now converging and are no longer as distant as they once were within the legal culture.

This is the crux of the matter. In our proposals, and I am glad that the European Commission has been convinced of these aspects, in our Convention we call for a change of direction, a bottom-up approach, with more legal studies than judicial training.

There is an example in the Netherlands called Eurinfra, which is very interesting. It is a network of coordinators in each court who disseminate this knowledge and encourage magistrates to engage with it.
Here is the essence of our project; we hope it will receive the full support of the Commission.

Thank you, President. Firstly, I would like to express my sincere appreciation for the work done by colleague Gigol on this initiative report. I also recall that together with him and others, we share an active presence in the cross-party group on the social economy of this Parliament.

My political group, as you know, believes that the social model is one of the founding characteristics of the European integration project, not just one policy among many, but a policy that defines our project itself.

And in these times, with attacks also linked to the need for public spending cuts, we still strongly defend this priority. We know that it can be an updated, modified social model, but we also believe that it should be maintained, protected, and reaffirmed precisely as a priority.

Therefore, I believe that within this same vision, we must also enhance the economic entities that run businesses, that produce goods and services, such as cooperatives, which play a very specific role in the so-called European social economy.

They reiterate that production is possible, good things can be done, and efficiency can be achieved even without profit as the goal. Instead, for example, one can focus on employment, welfare, the valorization of labor, and contributing to the life of the local community.

This is why, I conclude, Mr. President, it is important for Europe to provide the necessary tools for an active policy and to create a good statute, not the current one, which is inadequate, but a good statute for cooperatives can be a way to support this crucial sector.
Thank you, Mr. President. The role of the cooperative movement has always been significant in building a more balanced and fair economic dimension.

And at this moment, as we are going through one of the most severe economic and social crises since the postwar period, the function of cooperative societies becomes crucial. Indeed, it is evident that where there is...

there has been a robust development of the cooperative dimension in the economy, this has consequently led to an increase in employment, more qualified jobs, and a more balanced redistribution of the wealth produced.
It is therefore positive that the European Union has adopted a Statute for cooperative societies, but now more than ever it is necessary that there be a real simplification of the rules.
We need to give new impetus to the creation of a common European framework in the field of cooperation, and this must be done by helping and not creating bureaucratic obstacles.
For this reason, I voted in favor of this resolution and hope that the Commission and the Council will actively work to address the issues mentioned.

The plight of millions of European unemployed does not depend on the dual assistance offered by the European Fund for Adjustment to Globalization. The data collected highlight that most beneficiaries of the Fund are unable to find new employment, while the more fortunate are reintegrated into the labor market with fixed-term contracts of as little as six months.
In many cases, unemployed individuals give up on this fund because they doubt its usefulness.
The FEG is not a solution; it does not mitigate the disastrous consequences of a European trade policy that has been dangerously and recklessly managed by the Commission.

To combat the scourge of structural unemployment, Europe must curb its excessive openness to the markets of developing countries, whose real competition is the primary cause of the failures of our businesses.
Until Europe stops promoting economic self-harm by maintaining a short-sighted stance towards global trade flows, our businesses will continue to fail.
The fund can only provide temporary support, but it is not through training courses that our unemployed will find serenity and security.
